ygData.subject: Re: reusing a job and others questions
ygData.msgSnippet: ... notices ... Ok, I could see the notifications in jconsole. ... I don t think that it would be of use, at least we have not even consider using an instance

--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Michael Stack <stack@...> wrote:
>
=
> tizo_trico wrote:
> > St.Ack,
> >
> > Thanks very much for your time, and=
 sorry about my english.
> Your english is great.
> >
> > I have been testi=
ng JMX methods with jconsole, and I was able to
> > create a job, given an =
order file and a seed file, so one approach to
> > reusing a job (the first=
 we are testing), would be to hava a Java
> > program that creates jobs whe=
never needed.
> >
> > The fact is that we don't need a scheduling program p=
roperly said:
> > what we need is that a job be enqued again as soon as it =
finishes (at
> > least at the moment), so, is there any way to realize when=
 a job have
> > finished via JMX?
> You can poll the Heritrix instance stat=
us or you can register for JMX 
> notifications.  For illustration, see not=
ifications tab in JConsole for 
> CrawlJobs.  Enable them.  See how you get=
 different types of events: 
> progress stats on a period and notification =
of pause, etc. events.  Our 
> hcc application actually registers for notif=
ications from the JMX Agent 
> itself filtering for MBean creation/destruct=
ion.  This is how it
notices 
> the coming and going of jobs.
> 

Ok, I cou=
ld see the notifications in jconsole.

> Would it be of use if Heritrix cou=
ld shut itself down when asked to run 
> a job off the command-line? (IIRC,=
 we used to have something like this 
> functionality once) So, you'd do so=
mething like pass a command-line 
> argument that told heritrix shutdown wh=
en no more jobs to run -- '% 
> heritrix -r --shutdown order.xml' -- and he=
ritrix would run the one job 
> then go down?  Would that be of general use=
?

I don't think that it would be of use, at least we have not even
conside=
r using an instance per job.

> >
> > Another question is if others instanc=
es of Heritrix on the same JVM
> > can be created via JMX. I have made some=
 tests, and I could create
> > other Heritrix instances with the GUI admin,=
 in the url
> > http://localhost:8080/local-instances.jsp, and I could acce=
ss those
> > new instances with jconsole. What I could not find, is how to =
create
> > those with jconsole, is there a way to do that?
> >
> Not that I=
 know of. It may be possible in JConsole (or in other JMX 
> clients -- JMa=
nage?).  Its possible to create Heritrix instances via
the 
> hcc applicati=
on and via the little cmdline-jmxclient that comes in the 
> heritrix bin d=
irectory (See
http://crawler.archive.org/cmdline-jmxclient/).
> 

You don't=
 know if a new heritrix instance in the same JVM can be
created in jconsole=
, but could that be done in a Java program accesing
 Heritrix via JMX?

I a=
lso been testing cmdline-jmxclient, but when I execute "java -jar
bin/cmdli=
ne-jmxclient-0.10.5.jar controlRole:letmein localhost:8849
org.archive.craw=
ler:name=3DHeritrix", I get the following error:

Exception in thread "main=
" java.lang.NullPointerException
        at org.archive.jmx.Client.doBeans(=
Client.java:332)
        at org.archive.jmx.Client.execute(Client.java:312)=

        at org.archive.jmx.Client.execute(Client.java:278)
        at org.=
archive.jmx.Client.execute(Client.java:256)
        at org.archive.jmx.Clie=
nt.main(Client.java:159)

Should't that list available operations and attri=
butes? what I am
doing wrong? (If I execute without the last parameter, it =
runs OK and
list the differents beans).

And some questions about HCC: can =
it be used to control differents
instances of Heritrix IN THE SAME JVM on o=
ne machine? If the answer is
yes, can HCC create or destroy those instances=
?, or that should be
done in other way?

Thans very much again,

tizo





=
> St.Ack
> 
> > Thanks very much,
> >
> > tizo
> >
> >
> > --- In archive-c=
rawler@yahoogroups.com, Michael Stack <stack@> wrote:
> > >
> > > tizo_tric=
o wrote:
> > > > St.Ack,
> > > >
> > > > Yes, Yan Zhang's suggestion works;=
 I already have been working
in that
> > > > way, but I wonderer  if that c=
ould be done automatically.
> > >
> > > What would you suggest?
> > > >
> >=
 > > I have also thought in make a Java program that controls
Heritrix via
=
> > > > JMX, and creates jobs "based on existing jobs", as soon as they
> >=
 > > finished, but what about the seeds?, how can I recover the
same seeds?=

> > > I may be misinterpreting your question.  Are you asking how to reuse=

> > the
> > > same seeds in every job?  If so, as part of creating a job, =
you
specify
> > > the seeds to use usually by having the order.xml point to=
 a
seeds.txt
> > > file, the very file that was used in all previous crawls=
.  With
JMX you
> > > can pass paths to the order and seed file to use or p=
ass seeds as a
> > > string or pass a jar file that has the order and seeds=
 as well
as any
> > > settings overrides (The latter makes it easier postin=
g jobs to a
remote
> > > Heritrix instance).
> > > > Should the program its=
elf control the seeds for each
"reusable" job?
> > > > or there is a simple=
r way?
> > > >
> > > > Anyway, when you say "Automated rescheduling of jobs=
 is not
part of
> > > > the crawler.", is because it should not be part of =
the crawler?
> > > Thats what I think.  Keeps things modular and our option=
s open. 
> > > Scheduler can then be as simple as a cron job invoking herit=
rix
> > > command-line arguments or as sophisticated as quartz
> > > (http:=
//www.opensymphony.com/quartz/) 
> > <http://www.opensymphony.com/quartz/%2=
9> invoking Heritrix via JMX as
> > > originally suggested up on this list =
a while back
> > > (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/archive-crawler/message/1=
827). 
> > <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/archive-crawler/message/1827%29.>=

> > >
> > > > or
> > > > could it be a new functionality for future releas=
es? It the
last was
> > > > true, maybe I could work on that, but I don't k=
now yet,
because we are
> > > > studying the best way to implement the reus=
ability of jobs,
and one of
> > > > the alternatives is modifying Heritrix =
code.
> > > For sure it could be part of a future Heritrix and we'd welcome=
 any
> > > scheduling contribution.
> > >
> > > For our archive-it service =
we have a basic scheduler that lets you
> > start
> > > a job at defined co=
arse intervals (Once a day, once a week, etc.).
> > This
> > > 'scheduling'=
 is built into the application that manages all of the
> > > Hertrice insta=
nces each running distinct crawl jobs.  It does
this via
> > > the hcc Heri=
trix subproject: http://crawler.archive.org/hcc/ (hcc is
> > > beginnings o=
f a 'Heritrix Cluster Controller', an application
that can
> > > give a vie=
w onto a cluster of Heritrix crawlers).  If hcc had a
> > built-in
> > > sc=
heduler, our archive-it would likely use it. If it was part of
> > hcc, so
=
> > > could others.
> > >
> > > Myself, I don't see much value in adding a =
scheduler to Heritrix
> > itself:
> > > Another heavy jar, multiple specifi=
cation screens if the scheduler
> > is of
> > > any sophistication at all, =
and a new place on disk to worry
about  for
> > > persisted schedules.  I'd=
 be more interested in an external
scheduler
> > > that is able to schedule=
 multiple instances being part of a separate
> > > cluster-management appli=
cation but perhaps others see value in
building
> > > scheduling into Herit=
rix itself?
> > >
> > > St.Ack
> > >
> > > >
> > > > Thanks very much,
> > =
> >
> > > > tizo
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >

oogroups.com, Michael Stack <stack@>

use a job after it has finished? I mean,
> > after a
> > > > > > job finish=
es its crawl, could it be enqued automatically
again.
> > > > >
> > > > > N=
o.  Automated rescheduling of jobs is not part of the crawler.
> > > > >
> =
> > > > Will Yan Zhang's suggestion work  for you?  You could create and
> =
> queue
> > > > > up lots of the same job distingushed by a serial number a=
nd as a
> > crawl
> > > > > finishes, it'll start in on the next job.
> > >=
 > >
